questions.question: Which of the following statements about otosclerosis are correct? Otosclerosis primarily affects the region of the fissula ante fenestram, located anterior to the round window. The bony labyrinth is involved in otosclerosis, but the membranous labyrinth usually remains unaffected. Peri-otic duct is filled with endolymph. Otic capsule ossifies from 2 centers.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 2 only Explanation: Otosclerosis typically affects the fissula ante fenestram , which is located anterior to the oval window (not the round window). The bony labyrinth is involved in otosclerosis, while the membranous labyrinth is usually unaffected . The peri otic duct is filled with perilymph . Otic capsule ossifies from 14 centers. Anatomy of the Inner Ear: Otic labyrinth/ membranous labyrinth/ endolymphatic labyrinth : Consists of the utricle, cochlea, saccule, semicircular ducts, endolymphatic duct , and sac . It is filled with endolymph . Periotic labyrinth/ perilymphatic labyrinth (or space): It surrounds the otic labyrinth and is filled with perilymph. It includes the vestibule, scala tympani, scala vestibuli, perilymphatic space of semicircular canals , and the periotic duct (Statement 3) , which surrounds the endolymphatic duct of otic labyrinth. Otic capsule/ bony labyrinth: It has three layers: Endosteal : The innermost layer. It lines the bony labyrinth. Enchondral : Develops from the cartilage and later ossifies into bone. It is in this layer that some islands of cartilage are left unossified that later give rise to otosclerosis (Statement 2) . Periosteal : Covers the bony labyrinth. Development of the Inner ear: The otic capsule or the bony labyrinth ossifies from 14 centers (Statement 4) , the first one appears in the region of the cochlea at 16 weeks and the last one appears in the posterolateral part of the posterior semicircular canal at the 20th week.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of the inactive phase of otosclerosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Excessive osteoclast activity Explanation: The inactive phase is marked by dense hypercellular, sclerotic bone with minimal remodeling. Excessive osteoclastic activity is a feature of the active phase. Ossification and Bone Remodeling The otic capsule and ossicles undergo endochondral ossification, which is completed by the end of the first year of life. After this, minimal bone remodeling occurs, with few osteoclasts and osteoblasts. Otosclerosis occurs with excessive remodeling in otosclerotic foci. Phases of Otosclerosis Phase Features Histological features Active phase Characterized by Vascular proliferation Excessive remodeling (Option B) Increased osteoclast and osteoblast activity. The bone becomes spongy in appearance due to fibroblasts and histiocytes in the stroma, leading to the term otospongiosis . The new blood vessels are surrounded by a layer of new bone which stains blue on H and E stain hence known as the blue mantle of Manasse Inactive phase Marked by dense, hypercellular, sclerotic bone, with minimal remodeling (Options A, C , D) Mature foci show less vascularity and lay off more bone and more of fibrillar substance than cementum and are stained red. Reference: Logan Turner’s Diseases of the nose, throat, and ear, ed.11, page 434. Dhingra Diseases of the Ear, Nose, and Throat. Ed.8, page 104

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with progressive conductive hearing loss. During a stapedectomy, the surgeon notes that the stapes footplate is fixed, but the annular ligament remains free. Which type of stapedial otosclerosis is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Biscuit type Explanation: The biscuit type of stapedial otosclerosis is characterized by fixation of the stapes footplate while the annular ligament remains free. Types of otosclerosis: Stapedial otosclerosis Cochlear otosclerosis Histologic otosclerosis Stapedial otosclerosis causing stapes fixation and conductive deafness is the most common variety. Sites of stapedial otosclerosis: Type Site of the lesion Image Anterior focus Front of the oval window in an area called “fissula ante fenestram” Most common type Posterior focus (Option A ruled out) Behind the oval window Circumferential (Option B ruled out) Around the margin of the stapes footplate Biscuit type (Option C) In the footplate the annular ligament is free Obliterative type (Option D ruled out) Completely obliterates the oval window niche

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive hearing loss. She reports that she hears better in noisy environments, such as when talking to people in crowded places. This phenomenon is known as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Paracusis Willisii Explanation: Paracusis Willisii is a phenomenon commonly seen in otosclerosis, where patients hear better in noisy environments . This is because in noisy situations, people tend to speak louder, and the conductive hearing loss caused by otosclerosis allows patients to better perceive louder sounds. Features of otosclerosis Symptoms: Hearing Loss: This is the presenting symptom and usually starts in the twenties . It is painless and progressive and bilateral conductive type . Paracusis Willisii: An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. Tinnitus: It is more commonly seen in cochlear otosclerosis and active lesions. Vertigo: Uncommon symptom, can occur if vestibule is involved. Speech: The patient has a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech . Signs : The tympanic membrane is normal and mobile (90% of cases). Schwartze sign: A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane. This is indicative of active focus with increased vascularity . Fig: Schwartze sign Reference: Dhingra Diseases of the Ear, Nose , and Throat. Ed.8, page 104. Logan Turner’s Diseases of the nose, throat, and ear, ed.11, page 434.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man reports progressive hearing loss without tinnitus or vertigo. Otoscopy shows a normal tympanic membrane. Audiometry reveals a low-frequency air-bone gap with preserved speech discrimination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Stapedial otosclerosis Explanation: The patient has progressive low-frequency conductive hearing loss with a normal tympanic membrane and no tinnitus or vertigo , which is characteristic of stapedial otosclerosis . It results from stapes footplate fixation , causing a low-frequency air-bone gap on audiometry with preserved speech discrimination . Stapedial otosclerosis and cochlear otosclerosis are the two main types of otosclerosis that involve abnormal bone growth in the middle and inner ear. Feature Stapedial Otosclerosis (Option B) Cochlear Otosclerosis (Option A) Location Stapes footplate (attached to the oval window) Bony capsule of the cochlea Hearing loss type Conductive hearing loss Sensorineural hearing loss Effect on sound transmission Restricts movement of the stapes, impairing sound vibrations Disrupts cochlear structures, impairing signal conversion Vestibular symptoms Absent in most cases Vertigo or dizziness in some cases Frequency of hearing loss Lower frequencies affected first Higher frequencies affected first Tympanic membrane Normal - Other symptoms - Tinnitus (ringing in the ears) Presbycusis (Option C): An age-related bilateral sensorineural hearing loss affecting high frequencies. It does not produce an air-bone gap and would typically affect speech discrimination. Tympanosclerosis (Option D) is characterised by calcified plaques on the tympanic membrane or ossicles, often visible on otoscopy. A normal tympanic membrane in this case makes this diagnosis unlikely. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of the Ear, Nose , and Throat, 8th Edition, Page 104

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman with early-stage otosclerosis presents with progressive conductive hearing loss and a normal tympanic membrane. Which CT finding indicates the active phase of the disease?

options.A: Dense sclerotic bone around the stapes footplate
options.B: Lucent (hypodense) foci in the otic capsule near the stapes footplate
options.C: Erosion of the cochlear capsule with hypodense areas
options.D: Normal bone density with no abnormalities

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lucent (hypodense) foci in the otic capsule near the stapes footplate Explanation: In active otosclerosis , there is pathological bone remodeling in the otic capsule, particularly in the area anterior to the oval window known as the fissula ante fenestram . This phase is characterized by resorption of normal dense endochondral bone and its replacement by spongy vascular bone — a process referred to histologically as otospongiosis . On high-resolution CT of the temporal bone , this active phase appears as hypodense (lucent) foci near the stapes footplate, especially in the region of the fissula ante fenestram. This finding is subtle but highly suggestive of early, active disease , before significant stapes fixation or cochlear involvement occurs. Tests for Diagnosing Stapedial Otosclerosis Otoscopy Examines external and middle ear. Identifies abnormalities; typically, the tympanic membrane appears normal in otosclerosis. Fistula Test Evaluates inner ear response to pressure changes. Helps diagnose conditions like superior semicircular canal dehiscence, especially with vertigo. Tuning Fork Tests Weber and Rinne's tests differentiate conductive from sensorineural hearing loss. Less sensitive than audiometry but useful when other findings are inconclusive. Audiometry Pure-tone Audiometry Diagnoses and characterizes hearing loss. Gold standard for diagnosing stapedial otosclerosis . Initial low-frequency conductive loss progresses to flat maximal loss as stapes become fixed. Carhart effect may reduce bone conduction thresholds, noticeable at 2 kH Fig: Carhart notch (pure tone audiometry) Speech Audiometry Assesses speech understanding; not routinely used. High speech recognition with appropriate hearing aids. Stapedial Reflex Testing Assesses stapedius muscle response to sound. Reflex is often absent or abnormal in otosclerosis. Tympanometry Measures tympanic membrane and middle ear system mobility. Mobility is usually normal, but compliance may be low. Helps exclude other middle ear conditions. Imaging High-Resolution CT Scan (Option C ruled out) Sensitive and specific for active otosclerosis. The role of CT in stapedial otosclerosis is limited. CT is primarily used for atypical presentations or to evaluate cochlear otosclerosis , where it can reveal hypodense lesions in the otic capsule. Reveals hypodense lesions in active disease. Less effective for inactive disease due to dense otic capsule. Fig: HRCT of Otosclerosis Dense sclerotic bone around the stapes footplate (Option A): Seen in the inactive or late stage, reflecting bone deposition and fixation. Erosion of the cochlear capsule with hypodense areas (Option C): Suggests extensive cochlear involvement, more typical of advanced otosclerosis, not early active disease. Normal bone density with no abnormalities (Option D): Would not be expected in active otosclerosis; subtle hypodense lesions are usually visible with proper imaging technique.

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with sensorineural hearing loss. Pure-tone audiometry shows a sloping loss, and bone conduction testing shows a normal Carhart effect. High-resolution CT scan identifies otosclerotic foci but does not show clear cochlear changes. What does this finding suggest?

options.A: The CT scan results confirm a diagnosis of cochlear otosclerosis.
options.B: The normal Carhart effect suggests that cochlear otosclerosis is unlikely.
options.C: Cochlear otosclerosis should be considered despite the CT scan's inability to show cochlear changes.
options.D: The sloping audiometric pattern rules out cochlear otosclerosis.

questions.explanation: show cochlear changes. Correct Answer: C) Cochlear otosclerosis should be considered despite the CT scan's inability to show cochlear changes. Explanation: Cochlear otosclerosis should be considered as a diagnosis despite the limitations of the CT scan in visualizing cochlear changes. The presence of sensorineural hearing loss and a sloping audiometric pattern, along with the detection of otosclerotic foci, supports the need to consider cochlear otosclerosis Tests for Cochlear Otosclerosis Audiometry: Pure-tone audiometry : Sensorineural hearing loss is indicative of cochlear otosclerosis, unlike the conductive hearing loss seen in stapedial otosclerosis. Audiogram may show a sloping or notched sensorineural pattern rather than a flat conductive loss. (Option D) Bone conduction : Carhart effect (artificial reduction in bone conduction) may be less pronounced in cochlear otosclerosis, as the pathology affects the cochlea, not the ossicular chain. (Option B) Imaging: High-resolution CT scan : Useful for identifying otosclerotic foci in the temporal bone. May not clearly show cochlear involvement due to subtle changes like hyalinization of the spiral ligament. (Option A) (Option C) Diagnosis Approach: Medical History : Important to gather detailed information on family history of otosclerosis , hearing loss, and autoimmune diseases. Ruling Out Other Conditions : Exclude other causes of sensorineural hearing loss such as noise exposure, presbycusis, and inner ear disorders. Additional tests may include auditory brainstem response (ABR) and otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) . Reference: Logan Turner’s Diseases of the Nose, Throat and Ear, 11th Edition, Page 434, 435, 436, 437

questions.question: A patient who underwent stapedectomy for otosclerosis returns with complaints of dizziness and taste disturbances. Which of the following is a possible complication of stapedectomy that could explain these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Reparative granuloma Explanation: Reparative granuloma is a rare complication that can lead to abnormal tissue growth around the stapes prosthesis, potentially causing dizziness and taste disturbances. Complications of Otosclerosis Hearing Loss: Progression may occur even with treatment, especially with cochlear otosclerosis affecting inner ear structures. (Option A) Tinnitus: Persistent ringing or buzzing that may not fully resolve. (Option B) Vertigo and Balance Problems: Potentially caused by cochlear otosclerosis affecting the inner ear. Surgical Complications (Stapedectomy) Further Hearing Los s- Due to slippage of prosthesis or progression of disease, Infection (Option D), Dizziness, Taste Disturbances, Reparative Granuloma (Option C) Note: Most individuals with otosclerosis have a good prognosis with treatment and regular monitoring. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of the Ear, Nose , and Throat, Edition 8, Pg 104, 106.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive hearing loss in his left ear over the past few years. Audiometry shows hearing loss predominantly in lower frequencies, and otoscopic examination reveals a normal tympanic membrane. The patient denies experiencing tinnitus or vertigo. The patient’s hearing loss is mild and not significantly affecting his daily life. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Observation and monitoring Explanation: This presentation is consistent with Stapedial otosclerosis. In mild cases of stapedial otosclerosis where hearing loss is not significantly impacting daily life, observation with regular hearing tests is the preferred initial approach. Medical Management of Otosclerosis Management is individualized based on whether the otosclerosis is stapedial (middle ear) or cochlear (inner ear), focusing on hearing loss and quality of life. For Stapedial Otosclerosis Observation & Monitoring: (Option C) Recommended for mild cases or when hearing loss is not severe. Regular audiograms track hearing loss progression. Hearing Aids: Effective for conductive hearing loss due to the fixed stapes. Non-invasive option to improve sound transmission. For Cochlear Otosclerosis Hearing Aids: May help but are less effective for severe sensorineural hearing loss. Symptom Management: Tinnitus: Managed with sound or tinnitus retraining therapy. Vertigo: May improve with hearing treatment; other therapies could be needed. Medications for otosclerosis: Treatment Mechanism Duration Benefits Sodium Fluoride (NaF) (Option D) Stabilizes hearing thresholds and vestibular symptoms. Combined with calcium carbonate and vitamin D for enhanced effect. At least 6 months Delays worsening tinnitus Reduces conductive and sensorineural hearing loss Bisphosphonates (Option B) Stabilizes hearing loss, reduces dizziness and tinnitus. At least 6 months Stabilizes hearing loss Relieves vestibular symptoms Immediate stapedectomy surgery (Option A) : Surgery is considered in more advanced or symptomatic cases. In case of bilateral otosclerosis the worse ear is operated first and a wait time of 6 months is warranted before next surgery. C/I: Positive Schwartz sign, Pregnancy, active infection, only hearing ear, flying, diving and working at height. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of the Ear, Nose , and Throat, Edition 8, Pg 105, 106. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10008770/ https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22033-otosclerosis

questions.question: A 50-year-old patient is scheduled for a stapedectomy to treat stapedial otosclerosis. Which of the following statements about the stapedectomy procedure is false?

options.A: Small incision is made in the ear canal or behind the ear
options.B: Stapes bone along with its footplate is removed.
options.C: A metal or plastic prosthetic device replaces the stapes.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Lower complication rate. Explanation: Stapedectomy is associated with a higher risk of complications compared to stapedotomy, which generally has lower complication rates. Surgical Management of Otosclerosis Focus: Stapedial otosclerosis, which causes conductive hearing loss by affecting the stapes bone in the middle ear. Procedure: Stapedectomy Stapedectomy Steps Access: Small incision in the ear canal or behind the ear. (Option A) Stapes Removal: Removal of the stapes bone or its footplate. (Option B) Prosthesis Placement: Insertion of a metal or plastic prosthetic device to replace the stapes, functioning as a piston to transmit sound to the inner ear. (Option C) Fig: Steps of Stapedectomy Stapedotomy vs. Stapedectomy Procedure Description Complications (Option D) Stapedotomy Small opening made in the stapes footplate; a prosthesis is inserted. Lower complication rates; preferred by many otologists. Stapedectomy Complete removal of the stapes bone; replaced with a prosthetic device. Higher risk of complications. Outcomes Hearing Improvement: Effective for stapedial otosclerosis; many patients experience significant hearing enhancement. Cochlear Otosclerosis: Surgery is ineffective; it affects the inner ear and damages sensory cells, leading to sensorineural hearing loss which cannot be reversed surgically. Potential Complications Hearing Loss: Risk of further hearing loss despite a successful procedure. Infection: Possible risk of infection. Dizziness: Potential for dizziness or vertigo. Taste Disturbances: Possible due to proximity to taste nerves. Reparative Granuloma: Rare abnormal tissue growth around the prosthesis, possibly leading to hearing loss and requiring additional surgery. Contraindications: Single hearing ear Meniere’s disease Younger age group Otitis externa Workers in noisy workplaces Athletes, divers, and travelers
